revisions.rev:
{{Infobox civil conflict | title = 2011 Iraqi protests | partof = the [[Arab Spring]] | image = [[File:Location Iraq AW.png|300px]] | caption = | alt = | place = {{flag|Iraq}} | coordinates = | causes = <nowiki></nowiki> * Corruption * Poor national security * Poor public services * Unemployment * Saudi & GCC [[2011 Bahraini uprising#International military operations|intervention]] in Bahrain | date=February 2011 â ''ongoing'' | status = Ongoing | time = | timezone = | methods = [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]], [[riot]]s | injuries = | fatalities = 35 }} The '''2011 Iraqi protests''' came in the wake of the [[Tunisian revolution]] and [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egyptian uprising]]. It has resulted in at least thirty-five deaths, including at least twenty-nine on the 25 February "Day of Rage".
Several protests in March were against the [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]]-led [[2011 Bahraini uprising#International military operations|intervention]] in [[Bahrain]].<ref> reuters: [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/us-bahrain-iraq-idUSTRE72F4U220110316 Iraqis Shi'as stand with Bahrainis]</ref><ref>Associated Press [http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5igs1wV4hAVspBksbBZq7St89ViQQ?docId=0c4b1a5364514628baec418f05c59a7f Crackdown in Bahrain enflames Iraq's Shiites] retrieved 2 April 2011</ref>
[[2011 Kurdish protests in Iraq|Protests]] also took place in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], an autonomous [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] region in Iraq's north.
==Background== In an effort to prevent potential unrest, [[Iraq]]i [[Prime Minister of Iraq|Prime Minister]] [[Nouri al-Maliki]] announced that he will not run for a third term in 2014, and called for a constitutional term limit.<ref>{{cite news |title=Eye on unrest, Iraq PM says he won't seek 3rd term |first=Lara |last=Jakes |url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110205/D9L6OJH80.html |publisher=apnews.myway.com |date=5 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> Nevertheless, hundreds of protesters gathered in several major Iraqi urban areas on 12 February (notably Baghdad and Karbala) demanding a more effective approach to the issue of national security and investigation into federal corruption cases, as well as government action towards making public services fair and accessible. In response, the government of Iraq subsidised electricity costs.
== Protests == Israel's ''[[Haaretz]]'' reported that a 31-year-old man in [[Mosul]] died after he self-immolated in protest against unemployment. ''Haaretz'' also reported a planned "Revolution of Iraqi Rage" to be held on 25 February near the [[Green Zone]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Iraq man dies of self-immolation to protest rising unemployment |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/iraq-man-dies-of-self-immolation-to-protest-rising-unemployment-1.343162 |publisher=Haaretz |date=13 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
=== 12 February === Hundreds of protesters gathered in several major Iraqi urban areas, most notably in [[Baghdad]] and [[Karbala]], demanding a more effective approach to the issue of national security and an investigation into federal corruption cases, as well as government action towards making public services fair and accessible.<ref>{{cite news |title=Egyptian revolution sparks protest movement in democratic Iraq |first=Liz |last=Sly |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/12/AR2011021202100.html |publisher=The Washington Post |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Protesters In Iraqi Cities Demand Better Social Services, Corruption Probes |first= |last= |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/iraq_protests/2305822.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |date=|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iraqis anger spelled out in street protests |url=http://www.alsumaria.tv/en/Iraq-News/1-60223-Iraqis-anger-spelled-out-in-street-protests.html |publisher=Al Sumaria |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> In response, the government of Iraq subsidised electricity costs.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iraq subsidises power after protests over services |first=Ahmed |last=Rasheed |url=http://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFRAS22447520110212 |publisher=Reuters |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
=== 16â18 February === On 16 February, up to 2,000 protesters took over a provincial council building in the city of Kut. The protesters demanded the provincial governor resign due to a lack of basic services such as electricity and water. Up to three people were reported killed and 30 injured.
On 17 February, two people were killed as protesters threw stones at the headquarters of the Kurdistan Democratic Party, headed by Masoud Barzani, president of Iraq's semi-autonomous northern Kurdish region in Sulaimaniya, Iraqi Kurdistan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Two killed, 47 hurt in Iraq protest violence |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-iraq-protests-idUSTRE71G6PF20110217 |publisher=Reuters |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref>
On 18 February, around a thousand demonstrators blockaded a bridge in Basra, demanding the resignation of the provincial governor.<ref>{{cite news |title=Demonstrators block bridge in south Iraqi city |first= |last= |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4030474,00.html |publisher=Ynetnews |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref>
=== 23 February === Lt. Gen. [[Abdul-Aziz Al-Kubaisi]] ({{lang-ar|Ø¹Ø¨Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø²ÙØ² Ø§ÙÙØ¨ÙØ³Ù}}) resigned from his post as the Director General at the Iraqi Ministry of Defense, gave up his military rank, and removed it from his shoulders on television.<ref name=shorouknews>{{cite news |url=http://www.Shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?ID=395812 |title=ÙØ¹Ø±Ø§Ù Ø¹ÙÙ Ø·Ø±ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø©.. Ø¶Ø§Ø¨Ø· ÙØ¨ÙØ± ÙÙØ¶Ù ÙÙØ¯Ø¹ÙØ© ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¬Ù Ø¹Ø© |date=23 February 2011 |work=Shorouk News|publisher=Shorouk|accessdate=24 February 2011}}</ref> Following this step, he was arrested by security forces. Al Kubaisi described the Iraqi government as corrupt and called on all officers to declare their resignation and join the demonstrators, who are planning a demonstration on 25 February.<ref name=shorouknews />
The three officers, including one colonel, responded to this call and announced their resignations. Uday Zaidi, who has previously organized protests, revealed that these officers have joined the demonstrations. Zaidi told ''Al Jazeera'' that the 37 personnel from the Ministry of Interior have also resigned and joined the crowds of demonstrators.<ref name=shorouknews />
=== 24 February === On 24 February, [[Muntadhar al-Zaidi]], an Iraqi journalist famous for the 2008 shoeing incident, was arrested for allegedly taking part in the protests. Al-Zaidi is popular in Iraq for what Iraqis see as his act of defiance.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iraqi Shoe-Thrower Arrested for Supporting Protests |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/iraq/Iraqi-Shoe-Thrower-Arrested-for-Supporting-Protests-116858193.html |publisher=Voice of America |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2011}}</ref>
=== 25 February - "Day of Rage" === Major protests were held throughout Iraq on 25 February, centering on the nation's high unemployment, corruption, and poor public services.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tensions flare in Iraq rallies |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011224192028229471.html |newspaper=Al Jazeera English |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2011}}</ref> During the protests, crowds stormed provincial buildings, in addition to [[Prison escape|jailbreaking]] prisoners and forcing local officials to resign. At least twenty-nine people were killed across the country as a result of protests on this day, though the [[2011 Kurdish protests in Iraq|deadliest protests]] took place in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]].<ref>{{cite news |title=11 killed as Iraqis protest in 'Day of Rage' |first=Sinan |last=Salaheddin |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110225/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iraq |newspaper=Yahoo! News |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/02/26/3149626.htm?section=world |title=Toll rises as Iraq, Yemen protests rage |publisher=ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="wpdayofrage">{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/26/AR2011022601854.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Stephanie | last=McCrummen | title=Iraq 'Day of Rage' protests followed by detentions, beatings | date=26 February 2011}}</ref>
===26 February=== Protests were diminished from the 25 February "Day of Rage," due to the deaths that resulted during it. Hundreds were detained by Iraqi security forces, including [[journalists]], artists, and [[intellectuals]]. One of the artists that was arrested, Hussam al-Ssair, later stated that "It was like they were dealing with a bunch of [[al-Qaeda]] operatives, not a group of journalists."<ref name="wpdayofrage"/>
===16 March=== New protests arose at Baghdad and Basra against the [[Peninsula Shield Force|Saudi-led]] intervention in Bahrain.<ref> reuters: [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/us-bahrain-iraq-idUSTRE72F4U220110316 </ref><ref> reuters: [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/us-bahrain-iraq-idUSTRE72F6RSaudiJ20110316]</ref>
===17 March=== At [[Kerbela]] about 3,000 people demonstrated against Saudi-Arabia.<ref> http://www.neuepresse.de/Nachrichten/Politik/Deutschland-Welt/Anspannung-in-Bahrain-USA-machen-Druck </ref> Nuri al-Maliki critizised the Saudi intervention.<ref> Reuters: [http://de.reuters.com/article/topNews/idDEBEE72G08R20110317?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0] </ref>
===10 June=== About 400 protesters converged on Tahrir Square in [[Baghdad]] after Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]]'s deadline for reform expired.<ref>[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=hundreds-rally-after-iraq-deadline-expires-2011-06-10 "Hundreds rally after Iraq deadline expires"], Hurriyet Daily News. June 10, 2011. Accessed June 15, 2011</ref>
===12 August=== Dozens protested in Tahrir Square, calling for Oil Minister [[Karim Luaibi]] to be fired, a planned port named for ex-President of [[Egypt]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] to be scrapped, and [[political prisoner]]s to be released.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Alsumaria|url=http://www.alsumaria.tv/en/Iraq-News/1-67497-Iraqis-protest-in-Tahrir-Square.html|title=Iraqis protest in Tahrir Square|date=12 August 2011|accessdate=12 August 2011}}</ref>
==Responses== Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] said that his ministers who do not improve their ministries face dismissal. An MP also called for provincial elections to be brought forward by two years.
